introCards: Trigger Warning: This virtual gaming simulation contains sensitive information that may be triggering for some players. If at any time you are unable to continue playing, please take a break or stop immediately. If you continue to feel triggered, please use the resources provided to obtain support.

objectives.paragraph1: This virtual gaming simulation uses best practices for working with a client who is suicidal.
objectives.paragraph2: By the end of this virtual gaming simulation, you will be able to:
bullet_list: Apply best practices to assess the risk of suicide.
Select the best evidence-based techniques and skills needed to work with a suicidal client.
Evaluate the appropriate methods of action to ensure client safety.

instructions.paragraph: Watch the video story unfold. You will assume the role of a clinical nurse completing a client assessment.
bullet_list: Watch interactions between Kelly and the mental health counsellor
Following each interaction, you will be asked to select the most appropriate response. Possible responses are classified as: Correct, Not the best response, and Incorrect.
You can repeat this game numerous times for practice and to improve your responses.
The game can be paused and resumed at any time by leaving the game and returning to this page.
At the end of the game you will see a summary report with links to the suggested module readings.
This game has sound. Adjust your volume accordingly.
The game makes use of high-resolution videos, which require high-speed Internet.
The game will take 30-60 minutes to complete.

Trigger Warning: This virtual gaming simulation contains sensitive information that may be triggering for some players. If at any time you are unable to continue playing, please take a break or stop immediately. If you continue to feel triggered, please use the resources provided to obtain support.

principles.paragraph: This virtual gaming simulation was designed to employ the following essential principles:

decisionpoints.title: DP0
decisionpoints.message: How do you start the conversation with Kelly?

decisionpoints.title: DP1_2 - wrong
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response indicated that you made a strong assumption without gathering information. The response lacked empathy and did not allow the client to discuss what brought them into the centre. The response also inquires about a potentially very personal matter without giving the client a chance to acclimatize to the setting or to you. As a result, therapeutic rapport was not established and the client no longer wants services.
decisionpoints.message: How do you start the conversation with Kelly?

decisionpoints.title: DP1_3 - wrong
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response indicated that you were able to notice the client’s current state; however, the approach was too forward and caused the client to feel uncomfortable. This may not have been the best way to greet a distressed client. The client should be given the space to open up.
decisionpoints.message: How do you start the conversation with Kelly?

decisionpoints.title: DP2_1
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response indicated that you attempted to build rapport and create a safe space. By choosing this response your client was more willing to continue speaking with you.
decisionpoints.message: How do you help Kelly feel comfortable to open up to you?

decisionpoints.title: DP2_2 - wrong
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response lacked empathy and did not illicit trust or foster a working relationship.
decisionpoints.message: How do you help Kelly feel comfortable to open up to you?

decisionpoints.title: DP2_3 - wrong
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response asked an important question; however, the response overlooked the client’s emotional state and moved too quickly to an action-oriented question. This did not make the client feel comfortable to speak openly.
decisionpoints.message: How do you help Kelly feel comfortable to open up to you?

decisionpoints.title: DP3_1
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response was able to validate and normalize the client’s feelings and addressed their discomfort. In addition, the response invited the client to speak openly and displayed active listening.
decisionpoints.message: How do you gather more information?

options.label: Ask Kelly about reasons for making appointment
Ask open-ended questions to facilitate discussion

decisionpoints.title: DP3_2 - wrong
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response used language of blame and caused the client to act defensively. It can harm the rapport you have built so far.
decisionpoints.message: How do you gather more information?

options.label: Ask Kelly about reasons for making appointment
Ask open-ended questions to facilitate discussion

decisionpoints.title: DP3_3 - wrong
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response acknowledged the client has support; however, you were unable to effectively gather more information.
decisionpoints.message: How do you gather more information?

options.label: Ask open-ended questions to facilitate discussion

decisionpoints.title: DP4_1
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response reminded the client of their positive support. Your response also used a reflective question to gather information.
decisionpoints.message: How do you address Kelly’s unhealthy behaviours?

decisionpoints.title: DP4_2 - wrong
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response made the client feel judged and caused the client to shut down.
decisionpoints.message: How do you address Kelly’s unhealthy behaviours?

decisionpoints.title: DP4_3 - wrong
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response expressed some concern for her unhealthy behaviours and wanting to explore further. It made a connection to feelings. However, the approach may have been judgmental and may not have elicited an honest response from the client.
decisionpoints.message: How do you address Kelly’s unhealthy behaviours?

decisionpoints.title: DP5_1
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response acknowledged that there are negative impacts of the client’s unhealthy behaviours without judgement. Your response also asked open-ended questions to encourage discussion.
decisionpoints.message: How do you proceed?

decisionpoints.title: DP5_2 - wrong
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response seemed judgmental and was ineffective.
decisionpoints.message: How do you proceed?

decisionpoints.title: DP5_3 - wrong
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response used an open-ended question to gather more information; however, the question was too broad and did not demonstrate active listening.
decisionpoints.message: How do you proceed?

decisionpoints.title: DP6_1
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response paraphrased the client’s situation and reflected the client’s feelings. This response allowed the client to reflect on their behaviour.
decisionpoints.message: How do you inquire about Kelly’s support system?

decisionpoints.title: DP6_2 - wrong
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response assumes that the client considers her family a support system. Your response also appeared judgmental.
decisionpoints.message: How do you inquire about Kelly’s support system?

decisionpoints.title: DP6_3 - wrong
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response acknowledged the client’s need for additional support. However, you asked a closed-ended question and may have made the client feel uneasy.
decisionpoints.message: How do you inquire about Kelly’s support system?

options.label: Ask a general question about support

decisionpoints.title: DP7_1
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response acknowledged some of the client’s existing support system and you asked an open-ended question to gather more information.
decisionpoints.message: How do you find out more about Kelly’s coping mechanisms?

decisionpoints.title: DP7_2 - wrong
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response invalidated the client’s feelings and made her feel unimportant.
decisionpoints.message: How do you find out more about Kelly’s coping mechanisms?

decisionpoints.title: DP7_3 - wrong
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response slightly acknowledged the client’s stressors; however, the question asked was closed-ended and may seem judgmental.
decisionpoints.message: How do you find out more about Kelly’s coping mechanisms?

decisionpoints.title: DP8_1
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response acknowledged the client’s stressors, validated her need for support, and asked an open-ended question to gather more information.
decisionpoints.message: What is your response to Kelly’s admission of having negative thoughts?

decisionpoints.title: DP8_2 - wrong
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response seemed insensitive and ignored Kelly's admission of having negative thoughts.
decisionpoints.message: What is your response to Kelly’s admission of having negative thoughts?

decisionpoints.title: DP8_3 - wrong
decisionpoints.feedback: From the information gathered thus far, the question asked did not elicit information that would be useful to Kelly's current situation.
decisionpoints.message: What is your response to Kelly’s admission of having negative thoughts?

decisionpoints.title: DP9_1
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response displayed active listening and empathy. Your response also inquired about self-harm and suicidality to further access risk.
decisionpoints.message: How do you respond to Kelly expressing suicidal thoughts?

decisionpoints.title: DP9_2 - wrong
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response did not generate more information about the intent or plan to commit suicide which is needed to assess risk.
decisionpoints.message: How do you respond to Kelly expressing suicidal thoughts?

decisionpoints.title: DP9_3 - wrong
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response appeared too broad and was not able to generate additional information to assess for risk.
decisionpoints.message: How do you respond to Kelly expressing suicidal thoughts?

decisionpoints.title: DP10_1
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response helped to gather further information to assess the client’s risk level. Your response was also helpful as it inquired if the client was in imminent danger.
decisionpoints.message: How do you continue to assess Kelly’s risk of suicide?

options.label: Discuss impact of suicide on others

decisionpoints.title: DP10_2
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response elicits feelings about one of her sources of stress. This response was unhelpful as it places additional pressure on the client. In addition, it doesn’t get to the goal of assessing her current risk.
decisionpoints.message: How do you continue to assess Kelly’s risk of suicide?

decisionpoints.title: DP10_3
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response asked a question that generated information that was useful to assess the client’s risk of suicide; however, additional follow-up questions were needed.
decisionpoints.message: How do you continue to assess Kelly’s risk of suicide?

options.label: Discuss impact of suicide on others

decisionpoints.title: DP11_1
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response acknowledged that the client is contemplating suicide. Your response also asks whether or not the client has a plan to further assess risk.
decisionpoints.message: What would you rate Kelly’s risk level?

decisionpoints.title: DP11_2
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response is incorrect and may not have taken into consideration the current suicide plan or means to execute the plan.
decisionpoints.message: What would you rate Kelly’s risk level?

decisionpoints.title: DP11_3
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response may not have taken into consideration the current suicide plan or means to execute the plan.
decisionpoints.message: What would you rate Kelly’s risk level?

decisionpoints.title: DP12_1
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response identified that the client is high risk due to the current plan and means to execute the plan to take your life
decisionpoints.message: What is your first step to develop a safety plan?

decisionpoints.title: DP12_2
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response did not take into consideration that the client is high risk and needs immediate action. This response could place the client at further risk.
decisionpoints.message: What is your first step to develop a safety plan?

decisionpoints.title: DP12_3
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response was able to identify that the client needs support. However, involving her friend may not be the best option as this matter is urgent and requires more immediate action and we can’t be sure of Talia’s commitment to follow through on care.
decisionpoints.message: What is your first step to develop a safety plan?

decisionpoints.title: DP13_1
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response gently informed the client that the hospital would be the appropriate next step. This approach is appropriate as a preventative measure.
decisionpoints.message: How do you proceed to provide appropriate care for Kelly?

options.label: Discuss the need for further help
Discuss the need for immediate action

decisionpoints.title: DP13_2
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response did not take into consideration that the client is high risk and needs immediate action. This response could place the client at further risk.
decisionpoints.message: How do you proceed to provide appropriate care for Kelly?

options.label: Discuss the need for further help
Discuss the need for immediate action

decisionpoints.title: DP13_3
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response encouraged her to seek help. However, how to seek support was unclear.
decisionpoints.message: How do you proceed to provide appropriate care for Kelly?

options.label: Discuss the need for immediate action

decisionpoints.title: DP14_1
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response informed the client that her safety is the main priority. Your response also made it clear that the hospital is the next step to ensure her safety.
decisionpoints.message: How do you ensure Kelly goes to the hospital?

decisionpoints.title: DP14_2
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response was incorrect. Asking a friend to take her friend to the hospital is not a good choice. Putting the responsibility on Talia is not the correct way to handle this situation.
decisionpoints.message: How do you ensure Kelly goes to the hospital?

decisionpoints.title: DP14_3
decisionpoints.feedback: Your response to escort Kelly to the hospital may not be the best course of action for this high-risk situation.
decisionpoints.message: How do you ensure Kelly goes to the hospital?

decisionpoints.feedback: Your response may seem like an unconventional decision; however, calling the police is the best course of action. Sitting with Kelly and supporting her as needed while you both wait for the Police to respond is the correct decision in a high risk situation.
